text: Hi everyone. I am new here and trying to get to know the framework. I have purchased 1 month of historical soccer data to work with. Looking at the provided example for HistoricalData I would like to simply write a CSV that contains top 5 levels for ATB and ATL. With the example I can achieve this, but what happens is that I loop over the runners and write out the ATB and ATL, regardless of wether there was an actual change in the book. The reason is ofcourse that I loop over the runners on every message. What I would like to do write a CSV only when there is a change for 1 particular runner. Is this possible?

elements.text: Hi everyone. I am new here and trying to get to know the framework. I have purchased 1 month of historical soccer data to work with. Looking at the provided example for HistoricalData I would like to simply write a CSV that contains top 5 levels for ATB and ATL. With the example I can achieve this, but what happens is that I loop over the runners and write out the ATB and ATL, regardless of wether there was an actual change in the book. The reason is ofcourse that I loop over the runners on every message. What I would like to do write a CSV only when there is a change for 1 particular runner. Is this possible?

text: Theoretically you only get an update through the stream when there has been update but just create a cache of the runnerbook and if it has been updated record the data/cache and repeat

elements.text: Theoretically you only get an update through the stream when there has been update but just create a cache of the runnerbook and if it has been updated record the data/cache and repeat

text: This means I get called back whenever there is a change in any the market book as a whole?

elements.text: This means I get called back whenever there is a change in any the market book as a whole?

text: If a market book consists of 3 runnerbooks I would like to know which book changed and avoid going through all runnerbooks

elements.text: If a market book consists of 3 runnerbooks I would like to know which book changed and avoid going through all runnerbooks

text: there is no easy way to do this other than creating a cache, for example a dictionary with the selection_id and the data you want to record, if the data is different record it and update the cache

elements.text: there is no easy way to do this other than creating a cache, for example a dictionary with the selection_id and the data you want to record, if the data is different record it and update the cache

text: For a certain market the book looks like this: 5.9/26.53 6/37     +-+-+-   7.2/30 7.8/5   (i.e. available to back best price is 6 for size 37 , available to lay best price is 7.2 for size 30)

elements.text: For a certain market the book looks like this: 5.9/26.53 6/37     +-+-+-   7.2/30 7.8/5   (i.e. available to back best price is 6 for size 37 , available to lay best price is 7.2 for size 30)

text: then I see the following trades:  0.17@6.8, 0.17@7, 27.3@7.2

elements.text: then I see the following trades:  0.17@6.8, 0.17@7, 27.3@7.2

text: My question is the 2 trades at 6.8 and 7 for sizes of 0.17, they were not visible in the available to lay side of the book?

elements.text: My question is the 2 trades at 6.8 and 7 for sizes of 0.17, they were not visible in the available to lay side of the book?

text: Am I interpreting this correctly? This would mean there were hidden orders, or in the 50 ms timeslice these 2 orders came in and were immediately bought by someone?

elements.text: Am I interpreting this correctly? This would mean there were hidden orders, or in the 50 ms timeslice these 2 orders came in and were immediately bought by someone?

text: The market-after I see is also interesting: 5.9/26.53 6/37     +-+-+-  7.2/16.35 7.8/5 (i.e. the back side is unchanged, which makes sense, the size on lay side was reduced, but 30-27.3 = 2.7, while I see 16.35

elements.text: The market-after I see is also interesting: 5.9/26.53 6/37     +-+-+-  7.2/16.35 7.8/5 (i.e. the back side is unchanged, which makes sense, the size on lay side was reduced, but 30-27.3 = 2.7, while I see 16.35

text: So again, was there hidden size resting at 7.2?

elements.text: So again, was there hidden size resting at 7.2?

text: I'm assuming it is something like that, yeah (though I'd say Liam will know better), I'd say that it all starts with that initial 7.2/30

text: that if you had access to the individual offers at that price, it wasn't actually 30 whole euro at 7.2, it was in fact what you saw in the trade, ~27.4@7.2, ~0.17@7 and ~0.17@6.8

text: Do I understand correctly that in live-streaming data you can opt to see virtual (I would like them implied) prices? But when you buy historical data you only get the actuals back and lay priceladders. (Theoretically you could calculate the virtual prices yourself)

elements.text: Do I understand correctly that in live-streaming data you can opt to see virtual (I would like them implied) prices? But when you buy historical data you only get the actuals back and lay priceladders. (Theoretically you could calculate the virtual prices yourself)

text: You can return virtual bets in the response when using API-NG by including the virtualise":"true" in the listMarketBook request e.g. [{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "SportsAPING/v1.0/listMarketBook", "params": {"marketIds":["1.114101556"],"priceProjection":{"priceData":["EX_BEST_OFFERS"],"virtualise":"true"}}, "id": 1}]

elements.text: You can return virtual bets in the response when using API-NG by including the virtualise":"true" in the listMarketBook request e.g. [{"jsonrpc": "2.0", "method": "SportsAPING/v1.0/listMarketBook", "params": {"marketIds":["1.114101556"],"priceProjection":{"priceData":["EX_BEST_OFFERS"],"virtualise":"true"}}, "id": 1}]
